examples.en: The soccer tournament is on the 6th.
examples.ja: 六日は、サッカーの大会です。

examples.en: Every year at fireworks festivals, ice cream and hot dogs are popular.
examples.ja: 毎年、花火大会では、アイスクリームとホットドッグが人気です。

examples.en: You were the best in Japan at the marathon? Isn't that amazing?
examples.ja: マラソン大会で日本一になったの？すごすぎじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji> there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a <vocabulary>convention</vocabulary> or some kind of <vocabulary>tournament</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>event</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Did you know that Japan has entire <vocabulary>convention</vocabulary>s on <reading>tie</reading> <reading>kay</reading>aking (たいかい)? They regularly hold <vocabulary>tournament</vocabulary>s where they go kayaking using nothing but ties! Sounds pretty exhausting...

examples.en: Kawata is a very honest person.
examples.ja: 川田さんは、とても正直な人です。

examples.en: Please be honest. You're Nicholas Cage, right?
examples.ja: 正直に言って下さい。あなた、ニコラス・ケイジさんですよね？

examples.en: To be honest, I'm an adult but I can't go to bed by myself.
examples.ja: 正直、私は大人になっても一人でベッドに行けません。

meaning_mnemonic: It's always <kanji>correct</kanji> to say something <kanji>straight</kanji> to another person's face. This is called being <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary>. Are you an honest person?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both 正 and 直 have multiple on'yomi readings, and you haven't learned this reading of 直 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Be completely <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary>, what's the strangest sound you've ever heard? The <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) going "<reading>jiki</reading> jiki (じき)"?! <vocabulary>Honestly</vocabulary>, it sounds really strange... Maybe it's some kind of new samurai battle cry?

examples.en: Why do you extend your pinky when you drink from a glass?
examples.ja: なんでグラスで飲み物を飲む時に小指を立てるの？

examples.en: Ouch! I just hit my right pinky toe on the corner of the dresser.
examples.ja: いってぇー、そこのタンスの角に右足の小指ぶつけた。

examples.en: What happened? Your pinky finger is injured, isn't it?
examples.ja: どうしたの？小指、ケガしてるじゃん。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is your <vocabulary>little finger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pinky finger</vocabulary>. Makes sense, but it's also used for the pinky on your feet. You know, your <vocabulary>pinky toe</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

examples.en: I put butter in udon to give it a western-style twist.
examples.ja: バターを入れて、うどんを洋風にアレンジしました。

examples.en: Oh, is it a song from a Japanese artist? It sounded kind of like a western-style melody.
examples.ja: えっ、日本のアーティストの曲なの？なんだか洋風なメロディだね。

examples.en: My house is entirely furnished in the Western style, so there are no tatami mats.
examples.ja: 私の家は、家具を全て洋風に揃えているので、畳はありません。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 風 can mean "style" as in 和風? Well, this is now <kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>style</kanji>, more simply put as <vocabulary>Western style</vocabulary>.

洋風 is used to describe things with a Western look or influence, like 洋風の部屋 (Western-style room) or 洋風スープ (Western-style soup).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you think you'll be on good terms with Satomi?
examples.ja: さとみちゃんとは、仲良くなれそう？

examples.en: Don't those two get along?
examples.ja: あの二人、仲良くないの？

examples.en: Stop fighting and get along better!
examples.ja: ケンカばかりせずにもっと仲良くしなさい！

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>relationship</kanji> is <kanji>good</kanji>, that means you're <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> with that person. You're also on <vocabulary>good terms</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned already, so hopefully we can stay on good terms, right?

examples.en: I've just arrived at Narita Airport.
examples.ja: 今、成田空港に着きました。

examples.en: Once you know your arrival time, message me on LINE again.
examples.ja: 着く時間が分かったら、またラインして。

examples.en: The train didn't arrive on time.
examples.ja: 電車が時間通りに着かなかったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 着 can also mean <kanji>arrive</kanji>? This is the verb version of that meaning, so it means <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This uses a different kun'yomi reading than the one you just learned, but 着く (つく) has the same reading as 付く (to be attached). Because when arrive somewhere, it's like you're finally attached to your destination. If that connection doesn't quite click, here's another mnemonic: You wanted to arrive on time but you showed up late. How late were you? Two (つ) hours and two minutes late, to be exact.

examples.en: My boyfriend is a drinker.
examples.ja: 私の彼氏は酒好きです。

examples.en: That alcoholic is drinking in the morning again today.
examples.ja: あの酒好き、今日も朝から引っかけてやがるぜ。

examples.en: My wife is a drinker and I’m worried about her becoming an alcoholic.
examples.ja: 私の妻は酒好きなので、アル中にならないか心配だ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>like</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> a lot, you're probably a heavy <vocabulary>drinker</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (酒 and 好き) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of すき to ずき.

examples.en: Ugh, I don't even want to imagine!
examples.ja: ゲ、想像するのもヤダ！

examples.en: Please try to imagine that scene.
examples.ja: そのシーンを想像してみてください。

examples.en: Every once in a while Koichi will move in an unimaginable way while he's working.
examples.ja: コウイチは仕事中、たまに想像できないような動きをする。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>imagine</kanji> some sort of an <kanji>image</kanji> in your mind simply means <vocabulary>to imagine</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi has a one-hundred-million yen condo in Tokyo.
examples.ja: コウイチは東京に一億円のマンションを持っています。

examples.en: It's surprising that a small island nation like Japan has a population of over a hundred million people, isn't it?
examples.ja: 日本という小さな島国に一億もの人が住んでいるなんて、びっくりだよね。

examples.en: I heard you won a hundred million dollars in the lottery. Is that true?
examples.ja: 宝くじで一億ドル当たったって聞いたんだけど、本当？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> is <vocabulary>one hundred million</vocabulary>. That's a lot of zeros.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wait, does this painting really cost a hundred million yen?
examples.ja: え、この絵、一億円もするんですか？

examples.en: Oh no, the suitcase with a hundred million yen is missing! It was here just a moment ago.
examples.ja: やばい、一億円が入ったスーツケースがない！さっきまでここにあったのに。

examples.en: We don't get big, hundred million yen orders, but we do get steady orders.
examples.ja: 一億円とか大きな注文は入ってないけど、コンスタントに注文はあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> <kanji>yen</kanji>! So rich! You have <vocabulary>one hundred million yen</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We made five hundred million yen in sales this year.
examples.ja: 私たちは、今年は五億円を売り上げました。

examples.en: That doctor drives a three hundred million dollar car.
examples.ja: あのドクターは、三億ドルの車に乗っています。

examples.en: I have two hundred million friends.
examples.ja: 私は友達が二億人います。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, presumably because it's normally attached onto other numbers to signify how many hundred millions of ____ there are.

examples.en: It would be a big problem for Tofugu if WaniKani's revenue were to drop.
examples.ja: ワニカニの売り上げが落ちるのはトーフグにとって大きな問題です。

examples.en: I don't understand this math problem at all.
examples.ja: この数学の問題、全然分からないんだけど。

examples.en: "Can you look after my dog for the weekend?" "No problem. You can count on me."
examples.ja: 「週末、私の犬の世話をしてもらえないかな？」「問題ないよ。任せといて。」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>problem</kanji> <kanji>topic</kanji> is the <vocabulary>problem</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's 問題.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's doubtful whether Koichi actually can't eat meat.
examples.ja: コウイチが本当に肉を食べられないかは疑問です。

examples.en: I think a lot of people might have some doubts about that idea.
examples.ja: その考えには、少し疑問を持つ人も多いんじゃないでしょうか。

examples.en: Is that really necessary? Frankly, I doubt it.
examples.ja: それって本当に必要なんでしょうか。正直、私は疑問に思います。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>doubt</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is caused by having too much <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary>. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This bowl is my mom's.
examples.ja: この器は母のです。

examples.en: What shall we do? This is Koichi's cherished blowfish bowl, right?
examples.ja: どうしよう？これって、コウイチが大切にしていたフグの器だよね？

examples.en: That person really has a big heart, don't they?
examples.ja: あの人ってホント器が大きいよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

器 refers to a <vocabulary>container</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>bowl</vocabulary> and is often used in culinary contexts. It can also be used metaphorically to describe someone's <vocabulary>capacity</vocabulary> for certain things. For instance, when someone has a small 器, it means they have a limited capacity to handle pressure, stress, or difficulties.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You have this <vocabulary>container</vocabulary>. It's upside down with a stick holding it up and a string on the stick. You're going to catch some U2s (like, the band). You put some food under it and wait. Then, out of the bushes comes Bono. He sniffs around for a bit and then goes under the container. You pull! <reading>U2 wa</reading>lked (うつわ) right into the trap! Haha!

examples.en: Koichi is very dextrous with his fingers.
examples.ja: コウイチは手先がとても器用です。

examples.en: Viet skillfully drank a coca cola while wearing a WaniKani mascot outfit.
examples.ja: ビエトはワニカニの着ぐるみを着たまま、器用にコカ・コーラを飲んだ。

examples.en: She's always a cheerful and good girl, but her downside is that she's not very skilled.
examples.ja: 彼女はいつも明るくて良い子なんだけど、あまり器用じゃないのがネックなんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>task</kanji> is to open this pickle <kanji>container</kanji>. Why you? Because you are so <vocabulary>dextrous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary> when it comes to opening pickles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What's the name of this instrument? I've never seen it before.
examples.ja: これって何て言う楽器？初めて見た。

examples.en: Where should I buy musical instruments? Are there any stores around here?
examples.ja: 楽器ってどこで買えばいいの？この辺りにお店ってある？

examples.en: There are various different types of musical instruments. Which type do you like? I like percussion.
examples.ja: 楽器にも色々ありますが、どんな楽器が好きですか。私は打楽器が好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 and meant "music"? Well this is that 楽 again. A <kanji>music</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is something that can produce music. It is a <vocabulary>musical instrument</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 

You have already learned the reading for 器 but 楽 uses the secondary reading so you may not have learned it.  However, you learned this reading in the word 音楽. Just bear in mind that the がく shortens to がっ.

examples.en: Can you arrange these plates and utensils on the table, please?
examples.ja: この食器をテーブルの上にならべてくれませんか。

examples.en: Which utensils did you drop in the pond, the gold ones or the silver ones?
examples.ja: あなたが池に落としたのはこの金の食器ですか、それともこの銀の食器ですか。

examples.en: How come we have an extra set of tableware?
examples.ja: どうして、食器が１セット多いの？

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>container</kanji>s refer to <vocabulary>tableware</vocabulary>, including <vocabulary>eating utensils</vocabulary>, such as knives, forks, spoons, and chopsticks, as well as <vocabulary>serving utensils</vocabulary>, like plates, bowls, and saucers. Basically, it's stuff you use to eat your food.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the shortened しょく.

examples.en: My boyfriend is a sumo wrestler.
examples.ja: 私の彼氏は力士です。

examples.en: The sumo wrestler over there, he's a famous one, right? What's his name again?
examples.ja: あそこにいる力士、有名な人だよね？名前なんだっけ？

examples.en: I got an autograph from my favorite sumo wrestler.
examples.ja: 大好きな力士からサインをもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>power</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> isn't a samurai at all. A Samurai's all about precision, after all. So, imagine someone that's a huge mass of muscle (and fat). This Japanese warrior is all about power... ramming into people as hard as they can to knock them over. This person is a <vocabulary>sumo wrestler</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Have you done your homework yet?
examples.ja: 宿題、もうした？

examples.en: Can you take a quick look at my homework from today, please?
examples.ja: 今日の私の宿題、ちょっと見てもらえないかな？

examples.en: Stop making excuses and get your homework done already!
examples.ja: つべこべ言わずに、さっさと宿題をしなさい！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>lodge</kanji> you're staying in has a <kanji>topic</kanji> around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your <vocabulary>homework</vocabulary>. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This Shinjuku hotel's shower only has cold or lukewarm water.
examples.ja: この新宿のホテルのシャワーは、水かぬるま湯しか出ない。

examples.en: Wait, Maria is working part-time in Shinjuku?
examples.ja: え、マリアって新宿でバイトしてるの？

examples.en: Shinjuku 2-chome is now known as a gay town.
examples.ja: 新宿二丁目は今はゲイタウンとして知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>lodge</kanji> area is <vocabulary>Shinjuku</vocabulary>, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be careful of the しゅく changing to じゅく. Once again, will help if you've heard of Shinjuku.

examples.en: Adults have adult circumstances.
examples.ja: 大人には大人の事情があるんですよ。

examples.en: The police must take all circumstances into account.
examples.ja: 警察はすべての事情を考慮しなければならない。

examples.en: I understand the situation. I will talk to my superiors to see if we can do something about it.
examples.ja: 事情は分かりました。こちらで何とかならないか上に話してみます。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Occurrence</kanji>s and <kanji>feeling</kanji>s make up your <vocabulary>circumstances</vocabulary>. 

事情 is used to describe the <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>situation</vocabulary> behind a particular event or action. If you can't go to a party, for example, you might explain your 事情 by saying that something came up or you aren't feeling well. And if your coworker is expecting a baby, you might consider her 事情 and help reduce her workload.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In the past, people had more humanity.
examples.ja: 昔の人にはもっと人情があった。

examples.en: Yakuza value human emotions.
examples.ja: ヤクザは人情を重んじます。

examples.en: That person, despite appearances, is quite humane, aren't they?
examples.ja: あの人、ああ見えて、わりと人情家だよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Person</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are the <vocabulary>human feelings</vocabulary> every person has. They're the <vocabulary>humanity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>kindness</vocabulary> you feel toward others. 

人情 is often used in literature to describe the warmth found in human interactions and the heartfelt bonds they create. It literally means natural human emotions, but it's really about the kindness, compassion, and empathy people show toward one another.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He's a man without a shred of compassion.
examples.ja: アイツは情けのカケラもない男だよ。

examples.en: It's truly pathetic that I have to receive mercy from you.
examples.ja: お前に情けをかけられるなんて、ホント情けないよ。

examples.en: I got sixty-nine points on the test where seventy points is the passing score, but I was allowed to pass out of mercy.
examples.ja: 70点が合格点のテストで69点だったが、お情けで合格させてもらえた。

meaning_mnemonic: You have your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, <reading>KAY</reading>?? (け at the end)), you are asking them to <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> or have <vocabulary>mercy</vocabulary> on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary>. Don't kill me, man!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you begging to have pity on you? It's <reading>NASA</reading>. They have you hanging outside of the space station and they're going to push you towards earth where you'll burn up in the atmosphere. You don't want that, so you beg mission control for some <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary>. What will they do? You decide.

examples.en: I can't control my emotions well.
examples.ja: 私は感情のコントロールがうまく出来ません。

examples.en: That's a very emotionally charged way of singing, isn't it?
examples.ja: すごく感情がこもった歌い方だね。

examples.en: Do not give in too much to your feelings.
examples.ja: 感情に流されすぎてはいけないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Feeling</kanji> + <kanji>feeling</kanji> = <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>! It can also mean <vocabulary>emotion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can predict the future.
examples.ja: 私は未来が予想できるんです。

examples.en: My prediction turned out to be completely wrong.
examples.ja: 私の予想は見事に外れてしまいました。

examples.en: That was unexpected.
examples.ja: それは予想外でした。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you consider the future <kanji>beforehand</kanji> and <kanji>imagine</kanji> how things will turn out (based on some facts), you will have an informed <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prediction</vocabulary> for it.

予想 refers to an expectation or prediction about the future based on current information or trends, like predicting which candidate will win an upcoming election or estimating future economic conditions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I really like this retrospective scene in the movie.
examples.ja: この映画のこの回想のシーンがすごく好きなんだよね。

examples.en: Paul was lost in aimless reminiscence at the beach.
examples.ja: ポールはビーチで、とりとめのない回想にふけっていた。

examples.en: I know that Viet sometimes reminisces about his yakuza days during work hours.
examples.ja: ビエトが時々、仕事中にヤクザ時代のことを回想しているのを私は知っている。

meaning_mnemonic:
The past events <kanji>revolve</kanji> around your mind as you <kanji>imagine</kanji> them. That's a <vocabulary>reminiscence</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>recollection</vocabulary> of those times.

回想 refers to the reminiscence or recollection of past experiences or events. It's often used to describe flashback scenes in movies or dramas, as well as moments in literature where characters think back on their past.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can't go along with Koichi's ideas.
examples.ja: コウイチの思想にはついていけません。

examples.en: That person seems to hold some kinda strong views, don't you think?
examples.ja: あの人、ちょっと思想が強そうだよね。

examples.en: Of course, each person has the freedom to hold whatever ideas they wish in their heart.
examples.ja: もちろん、内心にどんな思想を持つかはその人の自由です。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>think</kanji> and <kanji>contemplate</kanji> deeply, you're producing something larger, like an <vocabulary>ideology</vocabulary>. This means having a group of, or a single larger, <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>(s) or <vocabulary>idea</vocabulary>(s).

思想 refers to the big ideas or beliefs an individual holds about the world and life. It’s often used to talk about one’s thoughts about philosophy, politics, religion, or other such beliefs.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 思 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

All your <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>idea</vocabulary>s are about <reading>shee</reading>p (し) right now. You just can't stop thinking about sheep. Are you thinking about sheep right now? What kind of sheep are they?

examples.en: If you had to lose one of your five senses, which one would you give up? Please also tell me why.
examples.ja: 五感のうちどれか一つを失ってしまうとしたら、どれを選びますか？また、その理由も教えてください。

examples.en: The dishes at our restaurant are designed to be enjoyed with all five senses.
examples.ja: うちのレストランの料理は五感で楽しめる料理となっています。

examples.en: Using all five senses in one's everyday life is very important.
examples.ja: 毎日、五感をしっかり使って生活することはとても大切なことです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are <vocabulary>the five senses</vocabulary> that you probably have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I agree with that opinion as well.
examples.ja: 私もその意見に同感ですね。

examples.en: I agree with this more wholeheartedly than I've ever agreed with anything in my whole life.
examples.ja: 今までにこんなに同感したことがないぐらい、思いっきり同感しています。

examples.en: "I hate Fugu." "I feel the same way."
examples.ja: 「私、フグのこと嫌い。」「同感だわ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
When you have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> as someone else, you are in <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary> with them. They have an opinion or feeling about something, and you're <vocabulary>feeling the same</vocabulary> way.

同感 is a word used to express agreement, often with a sense of shared feeling. You use it when you hear a thought or viewpoint that really resonates with you — you totally agree with this person's take and feel exactly the same way. Preach!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tofugu's drinking parties are so fun!
examples.ja: トーフグの飲み会はとても楽しいですよ！

examples.en: Forcing someone to chug a drink at a drinking party is alcohol harassment.
examples.ja: 飲み会で一気飲みを強要するのはアルハラだよ。

examples.en: My parents say that I can’t go to the drinking party.
examples.ja: うちの親が飲み会には行っちゃダメだって言うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 飲む is drink, so this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing. Also, 会 means <kanji>meet</kanji>, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a <vocabulary>drinking party</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the 飲む vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for 会. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!

examples.en: When I glanced back, he was still looking at me.
examples.ja: チラリと見返ると、彼もまだ私のことを見ていました。

examples.en: As I watched the fluttering of the turquoise butterfly, I suddenly glanced back at Mori-kun.
examples.ja: 青緑色のチョウチョウがヒラヒラしているのを見ながら、私はふと森君の方を見返りました。

examples.en: There was a huge crash and I involuntarily looked behind me.
examples.ja: ガシャーンと大きな音がして、私は思わず後ろを見返った。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>see</kanji>ing is <kanji>return</kanji>ing on something. This verb can be both transitive and intransitive. When it’s transitive, it means <vocabulary>to look back at</vocabulary>, in the sense of looking back at someone who’s behind you, or looking back at your past. When it’s intransitive, it simply means <vocabulary>to look back</vocabulary>, in the sense of looking over your shoulder.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are just 見 and the vocab word 返る, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.

examples.en: I met Hana-san at the beginning of April.
examples.ja: 花さんとは、4月の初めに出会いました。

examples.en: Our family goes to see the sunrise together at the beginning of each year.
examples.ja: うちは毎年、年の初めに家族みんなで朝日を見に行きます。

examples.en: It was Kaoru who first opened her mouth.
examples.ja: 初めに口を開いたのはカオルだった。

examples.en: You're the one who threw the first punch!
examples.ja: 初めになぐりかかってきたのはそっちだろ！

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 初 means <kanji>first</kanji>, and に can mark a point in time. So 初めに means <vocabulary>at first</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in the beginning</vocabulary>. 

初めに has a lot of overlap with 始めに. But while 始めに is for the beginning of some larger process, 初めに refers more to doing something first or to the initial point of a certain time frame. You might say 初めにアクビをしたのは私です (I was the one who yawned first), for example, or 今年の初めに (at the start of this year).
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

examples.en: Is this your first time in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本は初めてですか？

examples.en: I'm struggling with all these new experiences.
examples.ja: 初めてのことばかりで、四苦八苦しています。

examples.en: I've been interested in you since the first time we met.
examples.ja: 初めて会った時から、ずっと気になっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 初 means "first" This word means <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary>. Think of めて as "meet." Then think "when we met <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary> ____ happened."
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

examples.en: The 'Wind God' brought forth the divine wind.
examples.ja: 「風の神様」が、神風を起こしたんだよ。

examples.en: Thanks to the divine wind, Japan experienced a miraculous victory.
examples.ja: 神風のおかげで、日本が大勝利をするミラクルが起きたんだ。

examples.en: Five years ago, Koichi drove Viet’s troops back from his shores where they were swallowed up by a divine wind.
examples.ja: 五年前、神風が吹き、コウイチはビエトの軍隊を海岸から後退させた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Wind</kanji> of the <kanji>gods</kanji>. These are <vocabulary>divine winds</vocabulary>. More popularly, this is a word known as <vocabulary>kamikaze</vocabulary>, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of 風 from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word 神 to be able to read the rest.

examples.en: Oh, I'll help.
examples.ja: あ、手伝うよ。

examples.en: Sorry, could you help me out a bit?
examples.ja: ごめん、ちょっと手伝ってくれない？

examples.en: I really want to help, but there's nothing I can do.
examples.ja: 手伝ってあげたいのはやまやまなんだけど、私にはどうにもできないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji> to something or someone, you're putting out your hand <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> them or <vocabulary>to assist</vocabulary> them.
reading_mnemonic: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you've already learned! The thing is, the た from 伝's つた changes into だ for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> you to understand this dumb reading change.

examples.en: I am left-handed.
examples.ja: 私は左利きです。

examples.en: Do you have scissors for left-handed people?
examples.ja: 左利きの人向けのハサミはありますか？

examples.en: Are you right-handed? Or are you left-handed?
examples.ja: あなたは右利きですか？それとも左利きですか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>profit</kanji> from the <kanji>left</kanji>, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably <vocabulary>left handed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words 左 and 利く together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.

examples.en: We have physical education tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は体育があります。

examples.en: Before physical education class, please make sure to trim your nails.
examples.ja: 体育の前には、必ずツメを切って来てください。

examples.en: When is "Health and Sports Day" again? It's in October, right?
examples.ja: 「体育の日」っていつだっけ？十月だよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 教育 means "education?" Well, the 育 here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a <kanji>body</kanji> education. What do you call the body education at school? <vocabulary>Physical education</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>PE</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My son is not right-handed.
examples.ja: 私の息子は右利きではありません。

examples.en: Even though I'm left-handed, I accidentally bought a right-handed glove.
examples.ja: 左利きなのに、右利きのグローブを買っちゃったんだ。

examples.en: I really liked her, but things got awkward after I found out she's right-handed. I don't know why.
examples.ja: 彼女のこと、すごく好きだったんだけど、右利きだって分かってからムリになっちゃったんだよね。どうしてかは分からないけど。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> side of your body is the side you <kanji>profit</kanji> most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're <vocabulary>right handed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words 右 and 利く to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.

examples.en: Next, I plan to grow wasabi in the office.
examples.ja: 次はオフィスでワサビを育てるつもりです。

examples.en: Could you raise this puppy instead?
examples.ja: この子犬を私の代わりに育ててくれませんか。

examples.en: What did you raise as a class when you were in elementary school? Our class raised tadpoles, hamsters, and eggplants.
examples.ja: 小学校の時、クラスで何を育ててた？うちのクラスはおたまじゃくしとハムスターとなすを育ててたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is similar to 育つ, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means <vocabulary>to bring up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. You can remember this because of the てる. Your version of bringing a child up involves <reading>tear</reading>ing (てる) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 育つ. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.

examples.en: I think I'll catch up in about five minutes.
examples.ja: あと五分くらいで追い付くと思う。

examples.en: If you can catch up with Kristen in the hundred meter dash, you can compete in the Olympics.
examples.ja: 100メートル走でクリステンに追い付くことができたらオリンピックに出られるよ。

examples.en: I'm still trying to catch up emotionally a bit.
examples.ja: まだちょっと気持ちが追い付いてないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>follow</kanji> then <kanji>attach</kanji> yourself to whoever you're following is <vocabulary>to catch up with</vocabulary> someone.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes 追う and 付く combined.

examples.en: Are you planning to fight alone?
examples.ja: 一人で戦うつもりなの？

examples.en: Japan and America fought in WWII.
examples.ja: 第二次世界大戦で日本とアメリカは戦いました。

examples.en: My brother is fighting against an illness.
examples.ja: 私の兄は病気と戦っています。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the verb version of the vocab word <vocabulary>戦い</vocabulary>, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to battle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 戦い a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.

examples.en: I have no intention of pursuing Mari.
examples.ja: マリのこと、追いかけるつもりはないよ。

examples.en: He forgot his passport! I have to go after him right now.
examples.ja: あいつ、パスポート忘れてる！今すぐ追いかけなきゃ。

examples.en: I saw a lion chasing a rabbit over there.
examples.ja: あそこで、ウサギを追いかけるライオンを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: 追う means "to follow" or “to chase” and かける in this case means “to run,” so this word means <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pursue</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to run after</vocabulary> someone or something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 追う as well as the kanji reading you learned too.

examples.en: I'll order it on Amazon!
examples.ja: Amazonで注文するよ！

examples.en: I ordered wrapping paper covered in silver glitter.
examples.ja: 銀色のラメの入ったラッピングペーパーを注文しました。

examples.en: We could eat out or order takeout. I don’t mind one way or the other.
examples.ja: 外食でも、お持ち帰りで注文しても、僕はどちらでも構わないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You hopefully have seen the word 注文 (order, request). This is just the verb version: <vocabulary>to order</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the reading of 注文 you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.

examples.en: I love you.
examples.ja: 大好きです。

examples.en: No matter what he says, Fugu still likes WaniKani a lot.
examples.ja: なんだかんだ言っても、フグはワニカニのことが大好きなんですよ。

examples.en: I know it's not good for my health, but I really love McDonald's fries.
examples.ja: 体に良くないのは分かってるけど、マクドナルドのポテト、大好きなんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've hopefully seen 好き by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a 大 (big) like? You <vocabulary>really like</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>like a lot</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>love</vocabulary> something.

This is the same as 好き in that a more literal translation would be <vocabulary>lovable</vocabulary>, but it's generally translated as a verb in English.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 好き which you've hopefully seen. Then, 大 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The balloon escaped from the girl's hands.
examples.ja: 風船が女の子の手から放れた。

examples.en: I wonder how that dog was able to get off its leash.
examples.ja: あの犬はどうやってクサリから放れることができたんだろう。

examples.en: Once our son is off our hands, we are planning to live in the U.S.
examples.ja: 息子が私たちの手から放れたら、アメリカに住むつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 放す is "to release"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the releasing, something gets released or freed. So this is <vocabulary>to get loose</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be released</vocabulary>.

放れる describes something held in place coming loose and starting to move, like an animal breaking free from its tether or an arrow being released from a bowstring. You know this because it's pretty rare (れる) for something that's restrained to break free from its bonds. Escaping isn't easy, so it only happens on rare occasions.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same one you learned with 放す. If you can remember that word, you can apply the reading over here as well.

examples.en: That person seems unpleasant, don't they?
examples.ja: あの人感じ悪いよね。

examples.en: I really like the retro feel of this cafe.
examples.ja: このカフェ、レトロな感じがすごく好きなんだよね。

examples.en: What’s it feel like to be a company president, Mr. Koichi?
examples.ja: コウイチさん、社長になるって、どんな感じですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 感じる means "to feel." This is the noun version, which means a <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>impression</vocabulary>.

感じ is a casual word for the intuitive feeling or vibe something gives off. It doesn't usually refer to deep emotions, but rather the overall sense or atmosphere you get from a situation, person, or thing. This is one of those words you'll hear and use all the time — いい感じ (nice vibe), そんな感じ (something like that), どんな感じ？(what's it like?), and so on.
reading_mnemonic: If you can read 感じる, you should be able to read this too. It uses the same reading — just without る.

examples.en: How one feels varies from person to person.
examples.ja: どう感じるかは人それぞれです。

examples.en: Don't look at it, feel it with your heart.
examples.ja: 見るのではなく、心で感じてください。

examples.en: I feel like my older brother has been giving me the cold shoulder recently.
examples.ja: 最近兄に冷たくされていると感じます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>feeling</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to feel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?

examples.en: Oh, I want to be moved. Please let me know if you have any recommendations for moving films.
examples.ja: あー、感動したい。感動する映画のおすすめがあったら教えてください。

examples.en: This musical was incredibly moving!
examples.ja: このミュージカル、めっちゃ感動しました！

examples.en: We were also moved when we heard users say they were impressed by the WaniKani system.
examples.ja: ワニカニのシステムに感動したって言ってくれるユーザーさんの声を聞いて、私たちも感動しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know this is a verb from the する. Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are getting <kanji>move</kanji>d, so it means <vocabulary>to be emotionally moved</vocabulary> — describing how you're deeply affected by something. In English, this is sometimes phrased as <vocabulary>to be moving</vocabulary>, referring to the emotional impact something has, like a heartfelt movie.

感動する is used whenever something reaches you on a deep, genuine level, like when you're moved by an emotional speech, a touching story, or a stunning view.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You have such an admirable child.
examples.ja: 感心なお子さんですね。

examples.en: I'm so impressed that you study every single day.
examples.ja: 毎日勉強するなんて、感心、感心。

examples.en: Katie never ceases to impress me.
examples.ja: ケイティには、いつも感心させられっぱなしです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary> for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.

感心 expresses that you are <vocabulary>being impressed</vocabulary> by someone's effort, skill, or good behavior. You'll hear it when someone does something <vocabulary>praiseworthy</vocabulary> and you genuinely admire it, like 感心した (I’m impressed).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: If you don't mind, please let me know your thoughts.
examples.ja: よかったら、感想を聞かせてください。

examples.en: The homework is a book review for this book.
examples.ja: 宿題はこの本の感想文です。

examples.en: That's just your opinion, isn't it?
examples.ja: それってただのあなたの感想ですよね？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>feeling</kanji>s you <kanji>contemplate</kanji> about a subject are your <vocabulary>impressions</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>thoughts</vocabulary> on it.

感想 is all about what you think or feel after experiencing something, like after reading a book, watching a movie, or going to an event.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's show our gratitude to everyone on Thanksgiving Day.
examples.ja: 感謝祭の日にはみんなに感謝しましょう。

examples.en: I never say it out loud, but I'm always grateful to my parents.
examples.ja: 言葉には出さないけど、親にはいつも感謝しています。

examples.en: I can't thank everyone enough. It's because of all of you that I'm able to stand here.
examples.ja: 皆さんには感謝してもしきれません。私がここにいる立てるのは、皆さんのおかげです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>feeling</kanji>s of <kanji>apologizing</kanji>. Strangely, this word means <vocabulary>thanks</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gratitude</vocabulary>, though. Perhaps someone did something so nice for you that you want to apologize for how many nice things they're doing for you. You are this grateful to them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How much is the admission fee?
examples.ja: 入館料はいくらですか？

examples.en: The entrance fee here is too expensive.
examples.ja: ここの入館料は高すぎます。

examples.en: No admission fee is required today.
examples.ja: 今日は入館料はいりません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fee</kanji> for <kanji>enter</kanji>ing a <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>admission fee</vocabulary>. Gotta pay it if you want to get inside.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are gas bills expensive in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本はガスの料金は高いですか。

examples.en: Can you show me your fee plan first?
examples.ja: まずは料金プランを見せてもらえますか？

examples.en: No fee is charged for the first time.
examples.ja: 初回は料金はかかりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>fee</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (or money) you have to pay is a <vocabulary>fee</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary>.

You've learned 代金, which generally refers to the money paid for physical goods, but 料金 refers to a fee or charge for using a service — think bus fares, highway tolls, entrance fees, monthly service charges, that kind of thing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, a new movie theater has been built.
examples.ja: あ、新しい映画館ができてる。

examples.en: I love the caramel butter popcorn at the movie theater.
examples.ja: 映画館のキャラメルバターのポップコーンが大好きなんです。

examples.en: We're planning to see a new movie at the theater this weekend.
examples.ja: 今週末、私たちは映画館で新作映画を見る予定です。

examples.en: That movie theater is always practically empty whenever we go, so you can really relax and enjoy the movie.
examples.ja: あそこの映画館、いつ行ってもガラガラだから、かなりリラックスして映画が見れるんだよね。

examples.en: "Would you like to go to the movie theater tonight?" "I wish I could but I have to finish this paper."
examples.ja: 「今夜、映画館に行かない？」「そうできればいいんだけど、このレポートを仕上げなくちゃいけないんだ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You've already learned 映画 means "movie." A <kanji>public building</kanji> for movies is a <vocabulary>movie theater</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Huh? The screen is darker than usual.
examples.ja: アレ？なんか画面がいつもより暗い。

examples.en: Mr. Tanaka's room is always dark.
examples.ja: 田中さんの部屋はいつも暗い。

examples.en: I really hate all the gloomy news lately.
examples.ja: 最近は、暗いニュースばっかりでホントにイヤになります。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dark</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dark</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 
You're thrown into something <vocabulary>dark</vocabulary> and small. A lid is closed on top of you, and you are confused. What have you been thrown in? You find out you've been thrown in a <reading>cooler</reading> (くら). Feel afraid like you would be if you were thrown in such a dark cooler like this. Is it cold?

examples.en: That yakuza boss ended up getting assassinated.
examples.ja: そのヤクザの組長は暗殺されてしまいました。

examples.en: Have you already watched the Assassination Classroom movie?
examples.ja: もう暗殺教室の映画は見ましたか？

examples.en: Hey, Viet! How did you come up with such a unique assassination plan?
examples.ja: ねぇ、ビエト！どうやってこんなに面白い暗殺計画を思いついたの？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dark</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is an <vocabulary>assassination</vocabulary>. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm not good at memorization.
examples.ja: 暗記は苦手なんです。

examples.en: Oh, did you memorize this word for word?
examples.ja: え、これを丸暗記したの？

examples.en: He's the class clown and is always playing the fool, but he is very good at memorization.
examples.ja: 彼はクラスのお調子者で、いつもボケているが、暗記力はすごい。

meaning_mnemonic: In the <kanji>dark</kanji> if you try to <kanji>write down</kanji> something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is <vocabulary>memorization</vocabulary>! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi-sama can't stand it if everything isn't exactly the way he wants.
examples.ja: コウイチ様は、何もかもが自分の思い通りにならないと気がすまないんですよ。

examples.en: It would be rude if you don't attach the formal name ender, sama, to the recipient's name when you send letters in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で手紙を送る時には相手の名前に様をつけないと失礼になります。

examples.en: Mr. Koichi from Tofugu, party of nine. Your table is ready.
examples.ja: トーフグのコウイチ様御一行九名様ですね。お席のご用意ができましたのでどうぞ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You can add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it much, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Mr. Kawamura, what is your life's goal?
examples.ja: 川村さんの人生の目標はなんですか。

examples.en: First, let's set a goal!
examples.ja: まずは目標を立てましょう！

examples.en: I fired an arrow toward the target fifty meters ahead of me.
examples.ja: 五十メートル先の目標に向かって矢を放ちました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>signpost</kanji> you have your <kanji>eye</kanji> on is your <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>target</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>objective</vocabulary>. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your journey.
reading_mnemonic: You've had the on'yomi reading of 目 with 目次 way back in level 6. For this vocab, you're trying to get to your <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary>, that signpost in the distance. As you're trekking towards it there are people standing to the side <reading>mock</reading>ing you, telling you you'll never make it to your goal. Imagine this happening.

examples.en: My boyfriend kissed me on the bridge!
examples.ja: 彼氏に橋の上でキスされちゃった。

examples.en: What is this bridge called?
examples.ja: これは何という橋ですか？

examples.en: The name of that bridge is Nihonbashi. It was truly the central hub of Japan, as its name suggests.
examples.ja: その橋の名前は日本橋といいます。日本橋は、その名の通りまさに日本の中心でした。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! No need to burn any 橋s with this word and its kanji.

examples.en: How are you planning to kill that fly?
examples.ja: あのハエ、どうやって殺すつもりなの？

examples.en: I will kill you!
examples.ja: お前なんか殺してやる！

examples.en: My child is so timid that they can't even bring themselves to kill insects.
examples.ja: うちの子は、虫を殺すこともできないくらい気の弱い子なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>kill</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to kill</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <vocabulary>kill</vocabulary> someone! Oh no, what are you going to do? Where will you put the body? You decide to stuff it into the <reading>core</reading> (ころ) of a nuclear silo. It will melt and disappear in there, right? At least, that's what you think. Imagine opening up the core of the nuclear silo and feel the burn of the radiation. You throw the body in and close the core, then run away. Unfortunately, this nuclear core will kill you too, eventually. Then, it will kill everyone in the area, because the body you threw in will overheat the core, causing a giant explosion.

examples.en: I'm also not good with murder scenes in dramas.
examples.ja: 私はドラマの殺人のシーンとかも苦手なんです。

examples.en: Huh, murder at our school!? Is that for real?
examples.ja: えっ、うちの学校で殺人！？それ、マジ？

examples.en: I don't think this murder plan will go well.
examples.ja: この殺人計画じゃうまくいかないと思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When a <kanji>person</kanji> is <kanji>kill</kanji>ed, you have yourself a <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You must not commit suicide.
examples.ja: 自殺をしてはいけません。

examples.en: When thoughts of suicide arise, please call a helpline for help.
examples.ja: 自殺が頭によぎったら、すぐヘルプラインに電話してください。

examples.en: There are people who, through interacting with various individuals on forums, naturally refrained from suicidal thoughts.
examples.ja: フォーラムで色々な人とやりとりをするうちに、自然と自殺を思いとどまることができたという人もいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is when you kill yourself. That's <vocabulary>suicide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Eh, it's not like that at all.
examples.ja: え、全然そんなことないよ。

examples.en: "Excuse me. Can I ask you something right now?" "Yes, of course, go ahead!"
examples.ja: 「すみません。今、ちょっといいですか？」「はい、全然いいですよ！」

examples.en: I had no idea what he was talking about.
examples.ja: 彼が何を言っているのか、全然分かりませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you know <kanji>all</kanji> of something's <kanji>nature</kanji> then you know it <vocabulary>entirely</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>completely</vocabulary>. If you don't, then you know it <vocabulary>not at all</vocabulary>.

This word is weird. It can mean two opposite things depending on what kind of word comes after it. If it's a negative word, it'll mean "not at all." If it's not negative, it'll mean "entirely." Check out the patterns of use and context sentences for examples.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: "Wow! You scored a one hundred on that test?" "Naturally."
examples.ja: 「すごい！あのテストで百点とったの？」「当然さ。」

examples.en: If you want to become proficient in Japanese, it's only natural to practice even just a little every day, right?
examples.ja: 日本語が上手くなりたいのなら、毎日少しずつでも練習するのは当然でしょう！

examples.en: You are very lucky to have such a nice girlfriend. Don’t take her for granted.
examples.ja: あんな良い彼女がいるなんて、お前は本当に運がいいよな。当然のことだなんて思うなよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that's <kanji>right</kanji> by its very <kanji>nature</kanji> is <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>. 

当然 is also often used as an expression to mean <vocabulary>of course</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>naturally</vocabulary>. It's used when something is expected or goes without saying, like a confident "yeah, that's how it should be."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I love the nature of Japan.
examples.ja: 日本の自然が大好きです。

examples.en: It's natural to feel that way.
examples.ja: そう感じてしまうのは、自然なことですよ。

examples.en: We were told by the user to release WaniKani into the wild.
examples.ja: ユーザーから、ワニカニを自然に返すように言われました。

meaning_mnemonic:
To find your <kanji>self</kanji>'s true <kanji>nature</kanji>, go out into <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary>. Go out into the forests and fields, do some reading and thinking, and find your true nature.

This can also mean "natural" when it's used as a な adjective, like in 自然な日本語 (natural Japanese) or 自然な色 (natural color).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! Except 自 is し and not じ! That is because when you add the little dakuten you are adding to the し. When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> intended.

examples.en: You can do whatever you want as long as you have passion.
examples.ja: 情熱さえあれば何だってできるよ！

examples.en: We all teach Japanese with passion.
examples.ja: 私たちはみんな、情熱を持って日本語を教えています。

examples.en: Amazing! You finally found something you can pour your passion into!
examples.ja: すごい！ついに情熱を注げることが見つかったんですね！

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>feeling</kanji> the <kanji>fever</kanji>, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of  <vocabulary>passion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have a bit of a fever today so I can’t go out.
examples.ja: 今日は少し熱があるので外出できません。

examples.en: I'm a little feverish and sluggish.
examples.ja: ちょっと熱っぽいし、ダルいんだよね。

examples.en: Oh no, I have a forty degree fever?
examples.ja: え、やば。熱、40度もあるじゃん。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so don't get all feverish over this one.

examples.en: I like hot tea.
examples.ja: 私は熱いお茶が好きです。

examples.en: But this is a little too hot.
examples.ja: でも、これはちょっと熱すぎます。

examples.en: Our teacher back in our second year of high school was really passionate, wasn't he?
examples.ja: うちらの高２の時の先生、すごい熱い先生だったよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is for when a thing is <kanji>hot</kanji>, making this word <vocabulary>hot thing</vocabulary>. When the weather is hot that's 暑い. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as 暑い, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji 暑 at least. That uses the reading あつ. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.

examples.en: Everyone listened to the teacher very attentively.
examples.ja: みんな、とても熱心に先生の話を聞いていましたよ。

examples.en: This idol group has many devoted fans.
examples.ja: このアイドルグループには熱心なファンがたくさんいる。

examples.en: Saori's mother is very passionate about education.
examples.ja: サオリさんの母親はとても教育熱心です。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>fever</kanji>ish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of <vocabulary>enthusiasm</vocabulary> about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the ねっ portion (normally is ねつ).

examples.en: That is up to all of you.
examples.ja: それは皆さんが決めてください。

examples.en: I just want to get along with everybody. I absolutely do not have any ulterior motives.
examples.ja: 私は皆さんと仲良くなりたいだけなんです。決して下心なんてありません。

examples.en: Hello everyone. How are you?
examples.ja: 皆さん、こんにちは。お元気ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Everyone</kanji> + さん (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: This cat has green eyes.
examples.ja: このネコ、目の色が緑なんだよ。

examples.en: What, did you pick the green carpet?
examples.ja: え、カーペット、緑にしたの？

examples.en: This place is full of greenery, it feels so refreshing!
examples.ja: ここは緑がいっぱいで、気持ちいいね！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Why is this egg green!
examples.ja: この玉子、なんで緑色なの！？

examples.en: I bought red and green eyeshadow to create a Christmas-like makeup.
examples.ja: クリスマスっぽいメイクをしようと思って、赤色と緑色のアイシャドウを買いました。

examples.en: I feel like the green tie over there would be better, to be honest.
examples.ja: どっちかっていうと、そっちの緑色のネクタイの方がいい気がする。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>green</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is the color <vocabulary>green</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined!

examples.en: I practiced every day without fail for a year.
examples.ja: 一年間、毎日休まず練習しました。

examples.en: Have you practiced the piano today?
examples.ja: 今日はピアノの練習、もうしたの？

examples.en: You won't get better if you don't practice.
examples.ja: 練習しないと上手くならないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>practice</kanji> something to <kanji>learn</kanji> it. That's still called <vocabulary>practice</vocabulary>! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like poems a lot, so I read them every day.
examples.ja: 詩が大好きで、毎日詩を読んでいます。

examples.en: I started writing poetry when I was fourteen years old.
examples.ja: 十四才の時に詩を作り始めました。

examples.en: Today’s homework is to write a poem in Japanese.
examples.ja: 今日の宿題は、日本語で詩を書くことです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as the kanji as well! You are so happy that you could write a poem all about this...

The vocab reading
Is the same as the kanji
Crabigator love

How was that?

examples.en: Salmon is a poet who represents the current century.
examples.ja: サーモンは今世紀を代表する詩人です。

examples.en: I have a friend who is a poet.
examples.ja: 友人に詩人が一人います。

examples.en: He is a poet born in Canada.
examples.ja: 彼はカナダの生まれの詩人です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>poem</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>poet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We are learning how to write poetry.
examples.ja: 私たちは詩歌の作り方を学んでいます。

examples.en: Lately, I've been enjoying poetry.
examples.ja: 最近は詩歌をたしなんでいます。

examples.en: This is a radio program created for the enjoyment of poetry.
examples.ja: これは詩歌を楽しむために作られたラジオ番組です。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>poem</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji> is <vocabulary>poetry</vocabulary>. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.

詩歌 used to be for two kinds of poetry called kanshi and waka, but nowadays it's also used for other traditional Japanese poetry forms like tanka, haiku, senryu, and more.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know these readings, but there's usually an extra い in the middle. Don't worry, しか is totally fine too, but しいか is more common. You got this!

examples.en: I became a section manager last month.
examples.ja: 先月、課長になりました。

examples.en: I'm happy to have become a section chief.
examples.ja: 課長になれて、うれしいです。

examples.en: The section chief in our section is a bit annoying, you know.
examples.ja: うちの課の課長、少しうざいんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 社長 is the company president? This uses the same 長 meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since 課 means <kanji>section</kanji>, this is the <vocabulary>section manager</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I refuse to apologize for something I didn’t do.
examples.ja: 自分がしたことじゃないのに謝るつもりはないよ。

examples.en: Apologize to Koichi right now!
examples.ja: コウイチちゃんに今すぐ謝りなさい！

examples.en: No, why are you apologizing? You don't need to apologize.
examples.ja: いや、何でお前が謝るんだよ。謝らなくていいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>apologize</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to apologize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you say you're sorry <vocabulary>to apologize</vocabulary>, you'd probably start with: "<reading>I am</reading> (あやま) sorry!"

examples.en: Did you know that the prize money is actually on Koichi's head?
examples.ja: 実はコウイチの首には賞金がかけられているって知っていましたか。

examples.en: The prize money for this race is 100 million yen.
examples.ja: このレースの賞金は一億円です。

examples.en: When will I receive my prize money from the contest?
examples.ja: コンテストの賞金は、いつもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>prize</kanji> of <kanji>gold</kanji> is so old fashioned. We use cash now, which is why this word means <vocabulary>cash prize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My motorcycle's wheel came off.
examples.ja: バイクの車輪が外れてしまいました。

examples.en: Wait, do square wheels exist?
examples.ja: え、四角い車輪なんてあるんですか？

examples.en: I hit my little toe with the wheel of a tricycle!
examples.ja: 三輪車の車輪で足の小指を打ったんです！

meaning_mnemonic:
What part of your car are <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji>s? The <vocabulary>wheel</vocabulary>s, of course!

But 車輪 isn't just for cars! You'll spot this word rolling along with bicycles, motorcycles, carts, strollers, trolleys… you name it. It has a slightly formal or technical tone, so in everyday talk, you'll more often hear タイヤ (tire) when talking about vehicle wheels.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please throw this Quoits ring quickly!
examples.ja: 早くこの輪投げの輪を投げてくださいよ！

examples.en: If I go to parties, my circle of friends expands.
examples.ja: パーティーに行くと、友だちの輪が広がります。

examples.en: The angels danced in a circle, each of their halos shining brightly.
examples.ja: 天使たちは、それぞれの輪っかをキラキラさせながら、みんなで輪になってダンスしました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special <reading>Wa</reading>lken(わ) ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.

examples.en: My child always takes a long time to make a choice.
examples.ja: うちの子はいつも選ぶのに時間がかかるんです。

examples.en: You can choose whatever you like!
examples.ja: 好きなものを選んでいいよ！

examples.en: There are too many choices, and I can't decide!
examples.ja: 色々ありすぎて選べないよ！

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>"choose"</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have the opportunity <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>. You choose, and a bright sign lights up reading "<reading>error</reading>" (えら).

examples.en: Who is that handsome pro athlete?

examples.en: He is a Japanese professional baseball player who plays in Major League Baseball.
examples.ja: 彼はメジャーリーグでプレイする日本人のプロ野球選手です。

examples.en: I got an autograph from a player named  Darvish.
examples.ja: ダルビッシュ選手からサインをもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? Well this is one of them. In sports, you must <kanji>choose</kanji> the best <kanji>doer</kanji> for your team. In the world of sports, these "chosen doers" are the  <vocabulary>pro athlete</vocabulary>s and  <vocabulary>sports player </vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 選 is what you'd expect. 手 is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen 手 using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.

examples.en: The larger the oceanic fish, the more mercury in its body.
examples.ja: 海魚の体が大きいほど体内にたくさん水銀がたまっています。

examples.en: Why are both mercury and the planet Mercury called "mercury"?

examples.en: The flower that fell into the water appeared slightly mercury-colored in the moonlight.
examples.ja: 水に落ちたその花は、月明かりで少し水銀色に光って見えた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a fun one. <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>silver</kanji> is <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>quicksilver</vocabulary>, if you prefer.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you prefer silver or gold for the spoon?

examples.en: A silver pick-up truck pulled up alongside me.
examples.ja: 銀の軽トラが私の横に止まった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji.

examples.en: I think silver would be a good color for the eyes of this character.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just <vocabulary>silver</vocabulary> (the color).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is there a Mizuho Bank in this area?

meaning_mnemonic: Time to <kanji>go</kanji> get your <kanji>silver</kanji> from the <vocabulary>bank</vocabulary>.

examples.en: If you're looking for a hairbrush, it's in front of the mirror.

examples.en: Haha, you've got ketchup on your cheek. Go check in the mirror!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Every time I go to an all-you-can-eat restaurant, I end up eating too much.
examples.ja: 食べ放題に行くといつも食べすぎてしまいます。

examples.en: If we go to karaoke, why don't we choose the plan where we can sing as much as we want until the morning?
examples.ja: カラオケに行くなら、朝まで歌い放題のプランにしようよ。

examples.en: If you subscribe to Wanikani, you can study kanji as much as you want.
examples.ja: ワニカニをサブスクライブすれば、漢字の勉強がし放題ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Just <kanji>release</kanji> the <kanji>topic</kanji>... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and <vocabulary>as much as you want</vocabulary>. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next  couple levels.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The next topic is this one.

examples.en: We went to buy the much-talked-about fugu.

examples.ja: それ、SNSでめっちゃ話題になってたよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>topic</kanji> that we are <kanji>talk</kanji>ing about is the <vocabulary>topic</vocabulary> that we are talking about. It's the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of our conversation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It takes money to raise a family.

examples.en: Does WaniKani foster Tofugu or does Tofugu foster WaniKani?
examples.ja: ワニカニがトーフグを養っているの？それともトーフグがワニカニを養っているの？

examples.en: At our school, we focus on education that nurtures critical thinking skills.
examples.ja: うちの学校では、考える力を養う教育に力を入れています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>foster</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to foster</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. This can also refer to fostering a skill or ability, so can also mean <vocabulary>to develop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cultivate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you were a kid, your parent or guardian did their best <vocabulary>to foster</vocabulary> discipline as they tried <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> you. Why? Because of <reading>ya shena</reading>nigans (やしな)! Oh, they tried to cultivate discipline in you, alright — till ya shenanigans were no more.

examples.en: I heard that the station master's kid is actually an adopted child.
examples.ja: 駅長の子は、どうやら養子らしいです。

examples.en: My friend decided to give her baby up for adoption.
examples.ja: 私の友人は、赤ちゃんを養子に出すことにしました。
