meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>foster</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> you bring into your family is your <vocabulary>adopted child</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's a very nice ryokan!
examples.ja: すごくいい旅館ですね！

examples.en: I'm traveling to Japan next month. Where do you think I should stay: a Japanese-style inn or a hotel?
examples.ja: 来月日本に旅行に行くんだけど、旅館とホテルとどっちにステイするのがいいと思う？

examples.en: Why are there so many cockroaches in this Japanese inn?
examples.ja: なんでこの旅館、こんなにゴキブリが出るの？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you’re taking a <kanji>trip</kanji> to a <kanji>public building</kanji>, you might be staying at a <vocabulary>Japanese inn</vocabulary>. Those were very much public buildings for all kinds of travellers back in the day, when you think about it.

Alternatively, you could call this a <vocabulary>Japanese style hotel</vocabulary>, or just by its Japanese name, <vocabulary>ryokan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Next is Shinjuku Station.
examples.ja: 次は新宿駅です。

examples.en: I'm currently at the front of Ueno Station.
examples.ja: 今、上野駅の駅前にいます。

examples.en: I never thought I would run into you at a station.
examples.ja: まさか駅でバッタリお会いするなんて思ってもいませんでしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
reading_mnemonic: The kanji here uses えき as both its on'yomi and kun'yomi, so no worries here. You can go to this station or that station, and both stations will use the same reading as the kanji it comes from.

examples.en: I live in an apartment in front of the station.
examples.ja: 駅前のマンションに住んでいます。

examples.en: I saw my teacher in front of the station.
examples.ja: 駅前で先生を見かけたよ。

examples.en: If you're looking for a convenience store, it's located in front of the station.
examples.ja: コンビニなら駅前にあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>front</kanji> is the <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.
reading_mnemonic: This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for 駅 in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word 前 by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Let's ask the station attendant over there.
examples.ja: あそこの駅員さんに聞いてみましょう。

examples.en: There are no station attendants at this station.
examples.ja: この駅には、駅員はいません。

examples.en: Is there a station attendant who speaks Spanish?
examples.ja: スペイン語が話せる駅員さんはいますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A train <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at the train station. They are a <vocabulary>train station employee</vocabulary>. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today, my favorite idol is serving as the stationmaster at this station for the day.
examples.ja: 今日は好きなアイドルがこの駅で一日駅長をしているんです。

examples.en: Kawada-san is a close friend of the stationmaster here.
examples.ja: 川田さんはここの駅長と親友なんです。

examples.en: What?! That stationmaster used to be a professional golfer, right?
examples.ja: えっ！あの駅長、元プロゴルファーだよね？

meaning_mnemonic: This word uses 長 in the same way as 社長, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this 長 is the boss of the <kanji>station</kanji>, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the <vocabulary>stationmaster</vocabulary> (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you want to warm up the onigiri?
examples.ja: おにぎり、温める？

examples.en: I like to heat up milk and drink it.
examples.ja: 牛乳を温めてホットミルクにして飲むのが好きです。

examples.en: That idea is something I've been nurturing for a long time.
examples.ja: そのアイディアは私がずっと温めてきたものです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji 温 means <kanji>warm</kanji>, and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to heat something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warm something up</vocabulary>. It's all about you doing something to another object to make it hot, like putting it in the microwave.
reading_mnemonic:
The kanji reading is the same as 温かい. As long as you know that reading, you should be able to associate it with this word.

Just like you can say あったかい for 温かい, people often say あっためる in conversation. The "official" reading is still あたためる, so when typing out the kanji or taking a test, try to stick to あたためる.

examples.en: This apartment's residents' rooms are all neatly arranged.
examples.ja: このアパートの住民の部屋はみんなきちんと整理されています。

examples.en: I have not yet properly organized my thoughts.
examples.ja: まだ考えがちゃんと整理できていません。

examples.en: Today I organized the photo library on my phone.
examples.ja: 今日はスマホのフォトライブラリーを整理しました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something according to <kanji>reason</kanji>, the result is an <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Once you understand, let's move on to the next step!
examples.ja: 理解ができたら、次のステップに進みましょう！

examples.en: Our company president's ideas are always beyond everyone's comprehension.
examples.ja: うちの社長のアイデアは、いつもみんなの理解をこえています。

examples.en: I love you, sofa. Only you understand me.
examples.ja: 大好きだよ、ソファー。お前だけはオレのことを理解してくれる。

examples.en: I understand that oil and water don't mix.
examples.ja: 油と水が混じらないということは理解しています。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>reason</kanji> is <kanji>solve</kanji>d, you reach an <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> of something. You reach <vocabulary>comprehension</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like solving puzzles.
examples.ja: パズルを解くのが好きなんです。

examples.en: That boy genius was able to solve the mystery in three minutes.
examples.ja: その天才少年は、そのナゾを３分で解くことができました。

examples.en: He said, "I can solve this kind of problem in three minutes!" but even after three weeks, he still hasn't sent me the answer.
examples.ja: 「こんな問題、三分で解けるさ！」って言ってたのに、三週間たってもまだ解答が送られてこないんだよね。

examples.en: We are currently looking for clues to solve this code.
examples.ja: 私たちは今、この暗号を解くためのヒントをさがしています。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to solve</vocabulary>. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super <reading>coo</reading>' (く) to solve things.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There's something you've been trying <vocabulary>to solve</vocabulary> for your entire life: your <reading>toe</reading> (と). Why is it shaped like that? Why is it a little crooked? What's it scheming? Maybe one day you'll solve the mystery of your toe…

examples.en: Was there such an inn here?
examples.ja: こんな宿、ここにあったっけ？

examples.en: We still haven’t decided on a hotel yet.
examples.ja: 宿がまだ決まってないんだよ。

examples.en: This is a very famous inn.
examples.ja: ここはすごく有名な宿なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>lodge</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>. It is also considered to be an <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Yah do</reading> (やど) what you must to get <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>s for the night. Whether that's an <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary> or whatever. <reading>Yah do</reading> what you gotta do.

examples.en: Hey, isn't that Kaoru's boyfriend?
examples.ja: あれ、カオルの彼氏じゃない？

examples.en: I got this necklace from my boyfriend.
examples.ja: このネックレス、彼氏にもらったんだ。

examples.en: Oh, you got a boyfriend?
examples.ja: え、彼氏できたの？

examples.en: You know what, I get in a good mood just from talking to you. You really are my ideal boyfriend.
examples.ja: ねぇ、私、あなたと喋るだけで、いい気分になるわ。あなたって、私にとって本当に理想の彼氏だわ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>mister</kanji> is not just he, it's "mister he," and mister he is your he, your <vocabulary>boyfriend</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: She is Hana.
examples.ja: 彼女はハナさんです。

examples.en: I went to Disneyland with my girlfriend.
examples.ja: 彼女とディズニーランドに行ってきた。

examples.en: My girlfriend is so cute, isn’t she?
examples.ja: 俺の彼女、めっちゃかわいいだろ？

examples.en: She has good taste in clothes.
examples.ja: 彼女は服のセンスがいい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is <vocabulary>she</vocabulary>. Also could mean <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>, depending on how it's used.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the 彼 portion. Just think about how <vocabulary>she</vocabulary> (your <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>) is a <reading>canoe</reading> (かの), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.

examples.en: I'll have a draft beer.
examples.ja: 俺は生ビールにするよ。

examples.en: He's my buddy.
examples.ja: こいつ、俺のツレなんだ。

examples.en: Oh, that's okay, I'll do it.
examples.ja: あ、いいよ、俺がやるから。

examples.en: Hey Koichi, we’ve got a lot to catch up on.
examples.ja: やあ、コウイチ！俺、久しぶりにお前に会ったから、話したいことが山ほどあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Keep in mind that 俺 has a more informal and masculine sound than neutral options like 私 and 僕. While it carries a rougher vibe, it's not solely reserved for tough personalities and is very common in casual chats among buddies.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: We're freshmen.
examples.ja: 俺たち、一年生です。

examples.en: Those are our motorcycles.
examples.ja: それ、俺たちのバイクです。

examples.en: If no one else is going to do it, we'll have to!
examples.ja: 誰もやらないんだったら、俺たちがやるしかないだろ！

meaning_mnemonic:
When たち is attached to a word referring to a person, it makes it plural. So, when you attach たち to 俺 (<kanji>I</kanji>), it means <vocabulary>we</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>us</vocabulary>.

Just remember that 俺 is quite casual and rough sounding, so it's best to only use it with close friends (or when you're shaking someone down...).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is not juice. This is a can of beer.
examples.ja: これはジュースじゃないです。缶ビールです。

examples.en: Can you also get me a can of beer?
examples.ja: 缶ビールも1本、買ってきてくれない？

examples.en: I don't really like canned beer.
examples.ja: 缶ビールはあまり好きじゃないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>can</kanji> of <kanji>beer</kanji> (ビール) is a <vocabulary>can beer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>canned beer</vocabulary>. Not a bottled one.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Please put empty cans here.
examples.ja: 空き缶はここに入れてください。

examples.en: Why are there empty cans here?
examples.ja: なんでこんなとこに空き缶があるの？

examples.en: Empty cans should be recyclable.
examples.ja: 空き缶はリサイクルできるはずだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>can</kanji> is a can that has nothing but sky in it. It's an <vocabulary>empty can</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 空き isn't one you've seen before. Remember how 開く means "to open"? Well, this can is also open, because nothing is filling it. The readings are the same between the two, as well. 開く and 空く, though in this case it becomes the stem form: 空き.

examples.en: My dog is an old man and gets tired easily.
examples.ja: うちの犬はおじいちゃんなので、すぐ疲れるんです。

examples.en: I'm tired of thinking.
examples.ja: もう考えるのに疲れちゃったんだよ。

examples.en: Maybe your eyes are tired.
examples.ja: 目が疲れてるんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tired</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to get tired</vocabulary>. 

疲れる refers to a physical or mental kind of tiredness, like you just worked out or studied a ton, but isn't used to describe sleepiness.
reading_mnemonic: For example, you're bound <vocabulary>to get tired</vocabulary> if you try to lift <reading>two ca</reading>rs (つか), right? So think about that as you learn this word's reading.

examples.en: Cats will soothe you when you're tired.
examples.ja: ネコは疲れをいやしてくれるよ。

examples.en: Maybe it's because I'm old, but I can't shake off my fatigue easily.
examples.ja: 年のせいか、疲れが中々とれないんだよね。

examples.en: Our little boy is tireless and can run around all day long.
examples.ja: うちの子は、疲れ知らずで、一日中ずーっと走り回ってられるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
疲れる is "to get tired." This is the noun version, which makes it <vocabulary>tiredness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fatigue</vocabulary>.

疲れ is a more casual version of 疲労, so people commonly choose 疲れ over 疲労 in everyday conversation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 疲れる.

examples.en: Hokkaido is located in the north of Japan.
examples.ja: 北海道は日本の北にあります。

examples.en: Lavender and melon are famous in Hokkaido.
examples.ja: 北海道では、ラベンダーやメロンが有名です。

examples.en: I want to go to Hokkaido during winter vacation and eat some delicious crab, fish, and miso ramen.
examples.ja: 冬休みに北海道に行って、おいしいカニや魚とみそラーメンが食べたいです。

examples.en: My dad loves making the pun "Hokkaido wa dekkai dō." It's a play on the words "Hokkaido" and "dekkai zo" (meaning "it's huge").
examples.ja: 私の父は「北海道はでっかいどう」というダジャレを言うのが大好きです。これは、「北海道」と「でっかいぞ」の言葉遊びです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>north</kanji> <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is the road you take to get to the northern sea. This is the big northern island of Japan, actually, and it's called <vocabulary>Hokkaido</vocabulary>. It's a very nice place, so be sure to visit for some of the freshest seafood around.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ほく does get shortened though, so be careful!

examples.en: I'm starting to feel like a real parent at last.
examples.ja: ようやく親になる実感が持てるようになってきました。

examples.en: Even when I heard the news that my mother died, it didn't feel real at first.
examples.ja: 母が死んだという知らせを聞いても、すぐには実感できなかった。

examples.en: Only after I went to America did I realize how small Japan really is.
examples.ja: アメリカへ行って初めて、日本はなんと小さい国かと実感した。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>reality</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> is what you get when something feels real. The <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary> sets in — whatever this thing is, you've got a <vocabulary>real feeling</vocabulary> that it's actually happening.

実感 means a realization that comes from lived experience. For example, when you're expecting a baby, you may understand that you're becoming a parent, but not truly have that realization until the baby is born or you hold them in your arms. It's the sense of something feeling real beyond theory or explanation — when it truly sinks in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading for 実 gets changed to じっ so be careful!

examples.en: I don't want to break up!
examples.ja: 別れるのはイヤ！

examples.en: I broke up with my boyfriend last month.
examples.ja: 先月、彼氏と別れました。

examples.en: Wait, why did you break up?
examples.ja: え、なんで別れたの？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>separate</kanji>, so you can guess the meaning is <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 分ける? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from わける to わかれる. It's like we've "separated" the け and the る and combined them in the middle. け, making a かれ, which gets you to <reading>わか</reading>れる.

examples.en: How do you plan to share that data?
examples.ja: そのデータはどうやって共有するつもりですか？

examples.en: We share it internally using Dropbox.
examples.ja: 社内では、Dropboxを使って共有しています。

examples.en: Do you share images or videos with your family?
examples.ja: 画像やビデオって家族で共有してますか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is the same as 共有 but the verb version.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 共有 as well as the readings you learned via the kanji.

examples.en: I joined a volunteer assembly.
examples.ja: ボランティアの会に入った。

examples.en: We had a girls-only party last night.
examples.ja: 夕べ、女子会をしました。

examples.en: In Japan, when you go to school, the first thing you do is have a class morning meeting.
examples.ja: 日本では、学校に行くとまずクラスの朝の会があります。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>meet</kanji>, and it means a <vocabulary>gathering</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary>, as you’d expect! It isn’t really used for the kind of meeting you have at an office, though. It’s more in the sense of a people coming together for a specific purpose, like volunteer <vocabulary>group</vocabulary>, or a birthday <vocabulary>party</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: The population of Tashirojima is less than one hundred.
examples.ja: 田代島の人口は百人以下です。

examples.en: There are no gas stations on Tashirojima.
examples.ja: 田代島にはガソリンスタンドがありません。

examples.en: There are many cats on Tashirojima Island.
examples.ja: 田代島にはネコがたくさんいます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is used as a <kanji>substitute</kanji> for an <kanji>island</kanji>. Which island is it? That's right, <vocabulary>Tashirojima</vocabulary>. Imagine a rice paddy in the middle of the sea, standing in for <vocabulary>Tashiro Island</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic:
This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned this particular kun'yomi for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

When you go to <vocabulary>Tashirojima</vocabulary>, make sure you visit the old woman. You know what woman I'm talking about, the one who starred on Murder <reading>she wro</reading>te (しろ). She writes a lot about cats now, I guess.

examples.en: I really like the expression on the girl's face in this illustration.
examples.ja: このイラストの女の子の表情、めっちゃいいね。

examples.en: Hey, your expression seems softer now.
examples.ja: アンタ、なんか表情がソフトになったね。

examples.en: My child always has a stiff expression, you know?
examples.ja: うちの子、いつも表情がカタイんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>express</kanji> a <kanji>feeling</kanji> it shows on your face. This is called a <vocabulary>facial expression</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A cat licked my middle finger.
examples.ja: ネコに中指をなめられました。

examples.en: I got a callus on my middle finger.
examples.ja: 中指にタコができちゃいました。

examples.en: Don’t stick out your middle finger!
examples.ja: 中指を立てるんじゃない！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle finger</vocabulary>, of course! And because we don't see the difference, it's your <vocabulary>middle toe</vocabulary> too. Stick that up the next time someone makes you mad.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

examples.en: She's my goddess!
examples.ja: 彼女はオレの女神様なんだ！

examples.en: You are as beautiful as a goddess.
examples.ja: あなたは女神のように美しいですね。

examples.en: Did you know that the Statue of Liberty is actually located in New Jersey, not New York?
examples.ja: 実は、自由の女神があるのは、ニューヨーク州じゃなく、ニュージャージー州だって知っていましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>woman</kanji> who is also a <kanji>god</kanji> is a <vocabulary>goddess</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 女 yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

This <vocabulary>goddess</vocabulary> has the most beautiful <reading>目</reading> (め) you've ever seen. You can't stop staring into them. This must be how people know they've met a god.

examples.en: Scholarship is always associated with literature.
examples.ja: 学問と文学は切っても切れない関係にある。

examples.en: Academic freedom was lost due to the war.
examples.ja: 戦争によって、学問の自由は失われたんです。

examples.en: This shrine is known as a shrine where the god of learning resides.
examples.ja: この神社は、学問の神様のいる神社として知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: How can you solve your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji>? With a little extra <vocabulary>schooling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>learning</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Don't worry. That is to be expected.
examples.ja: 心配いりません。それは想定内です。

examples.en: Even if unexpected things happen, I am training myself to remain calm and act accordingly.
examples.ja: 想定外のことが起きても、落ち着いて行動できるようトレーニングを重ねています。

examples.en: We will now conduct the disaster drill assuming there is an earthquake.
examples.ja: 地震を想定した避難訓練を行います。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>imagine</kanji> something that's somewhat <kanji>determine</kanji>d, that means you already have some sort of <vocabulary>assumption</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> about it.

想定 usually refers to assumptions made in advance about certain conditions or situations. It’s often used when talking about preparing for or anticipating future events, especially ones where planning might be required, like natural disasters.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The king loves cooking.
examples.ja: 王様は料理が大好きです。

examples.en: That king is ridiculously stingy.
examples.ja: あの王様は、とんでもなくケチなんだ。

examples.en: Have you seen the image of that king yet?
examples.ja: あの王様の画像、もう見ましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>king</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is the <vocabulary>king</vocabulary>, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you!
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 王 and the kun'yomi reading for 様. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: Let go of my thumb!
examples.ja: 親指を放してくれ！

examples.en: Everyone in my family has a mole on their thumb.
examples.ja: うちの家族は全員親指にホクロがあります。

examples.en: I got a wart on my big toe.
examples.ja: 足の親指にイボができました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is your <vocabulary>thumb</vocabulary>! It's bigger than your other fingers, so that means it's in charge too! This goes for the fingers on your feet too, I mean, your toes. So the parent toe is your <vocabulary>big toe</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

examples.en: The one over there is a god.
examples.ja: あそこにいるのは神様です。

examples.en: Who comes to your mind when you hear the name "guitar god."
examples.ja: ギターの神様と言えば、誰を思いうかべますか？

examples.en: That's probably just the god of mischief.
examples.ja: あれは多分神様のイタズラだったのだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>God</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is <vocabulary>God</vocabulary>! Or the <vocabulary>gods</vocabulary>, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: Don't you think Maria has such a sexy mole on the tip of her left pinky?
examples.ja: マリアって、左の小指の指先のホクロがセクシーだよね？

examples.en: Koichi is in the habit of spinning a soccer ball on his fingertip while he's thinking.
examples.ja: コウイチは、考え事をしている時、サッカーボールを指先でクルクルと回すクセがあります。

examples.en: Your fingertips are red.
examples.ja: 指先が赤くなってるね。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>finger</kanji>? The part I just chopped off? Well that was your <vocabulary>fingertip</vocabulary>! I only had time to get the tip. It used to be on your finger and now it's right here, in my hand. Sorry, I guess. Oh, but don't worry, I'll even things out and get the tip of your toe real quick too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

examples.en: Our boss's painting won the special prize at the contest!
examples.ja: 親分の絵が、コンクールで特選に入賞したぞ！

examples.en: Tonight's dinner is premium Japanese beef shabu-shabu.
examples.ja: 今日のディナーは特選和牛のシャブシャブです。

examples.en: I received a gift of premium rice from the company president.
examples.ja: 社長から特選米をプレゼントしていただきました。

meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>special</kanji> you <kanji>choose</kanji> it. That makes it a <vocabulary>special selection</vocabulary> of yours and it gets a <vocabulary>special prize</vocabulary> that only you could give!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Yay! I got accepted into a university in Seattle!
examples.ja: やった！シアトル市の大学に受かったよ！

examples.en: If you don't pass next time, you'll have fewer chances of becoming a doctor.
examples.ja: 次回受からなければ、医者になれるチャンスは少なくなるよ。

examples.en: I made a resolution that I won't go out on weekends until I pass my exams.
examples.ja: 試験に受かるまで週末は出かけないって決心したんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 受 means accept and this verb is related. It means to get accepted, usually into something good like a university or a new job. It can also mean to pass, often in the context of a test or an exam. This is an intransitive verb, so no direct object is needed. A hint for this is that it ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive. Also, be careful: in English you'd use the transitive expression "pass a test," but in Japanese you'd say 試験に受かる. Kind of like saying you pass in the exam — so it's still intransitive!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Here's a little mnemonic to help ya remember:

<vocabulary>To get accepted</vocabulary> into this program, you have to juggle <reading>u</reading>nis (う)—yes, those spiky sea urchins! Handling uni is tough, but if you want <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary> the test and get accepted, you've got to master the uni challenge.

examples.en: This in an image of Uranus.
examples.ja: これは天王星の画像です。

examples.en: The discoverer of Uranus is William Herschel.
examples.ja: 天王星の発見者はウィリアム・ハーシェルです。

examples.en: Uranus takes eighty-four years to complete an orbit.
examples.ja: 天王星は一回りするのに八十四年かかります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Uranus</vocabulary>. Knowledge of Greek mythology will definitely help you here, because the English name is a reference to the Greek god of the skies, and the Japanese name is a direct translation of that!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi, but over time the reading for 王 changed from おう to のう, to make it easier to pronounce. You'll still see that listed as an alternative reading in some dictionaries, but it's pretty much never used nowadays, so we'll only accept the てんのうせい reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Who predicted the discovery of <vocabulary>Uranus</vocabulary>? <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう), of course!

examples.en: That dress is so cute!
examples.ja: そのワンピース、めっちゃかわいいね！

examples.en: I bought five dresses at a bargain sale.
examples.ja: バーゲンで、ワンピースを五着も買っちゃった。

examples.en: I spilled coffee on my favorite white dress.
examples.ja: お気に入りの白いワンピースにコーヒーをこぼしてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: ワンピース comes from the English word one-piece, but it generally refers to a casual <vocabulary>dress</vocabulary> in Japanese.

examples.en: We can see the fireworks really well from the balcony of my apartment!
examples.ja: うちのマンションのベランダから、花火めっちゃよく見えるよ！

examples.en: Huh, you'd rather live in an apartment than in your own house? Why?
examples.ja: えーっ、マイホームよりマンションに住む方がいいの？なんで？

examples.en: I'm planning to leave this apartment next month.
examples.ja: 私、来月、このマンションを出る予定なんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: マンション comes from the English word "mansion," but it just means an ordinary <vocabulary>apartment building</vocabulary> in Japanese. Depending on context, it can also mean an individual <vocabulary>apartment</vocabulary>. Either way, it’s definitely not a big, luxurious house in Japanese!

examples.en: When Masao's glass became empty, Michiko quietly poured wine into it.
examples.ja: マサオのグラスが空くと、ミチコはそっとワインを注いだ。

examples.en: Please let me know the days when your schedule is free.
examples.ja: スケジュールが空いてる日を教えてください。

examples.en: Luckily, there was one available table, so we were able to get seated at the restaurant right away.
examples.ja: ラッキーなことに、テーブルが一つ空いていたのですぐ店に入れました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the kanji for <kanji>empty</kanji>, so this verb means <vocabulary>to become empty</vocabulary>. 

It can also have a slightly different meaning when it's read differently, but you'll learn this through other words later on, so don't worry about it for now.
reading_mnemonic: Whenever something is about <vocabulary>to become empty</vocabulary>, you can't help saying "<reading>Ah…</reading>" (あ) to express your disappointment. Your glass of water is becoming empty? Ah… Your bag of chips is becoming empty? Ah… Exclaiming a little "Ah…" is the only thing that helps you cope with the sadness of your favorite things becoming empty.
